Deferring the proof of Theorem 2' for a moment,  we note that the result essentially generalizes Poisson's problem by replacing the fixed plane with a piece 5^ of a minimal surface having a single valued projection in some fixed direction.  That is,  if the spatial boundary lies " suitably near " 6^ then it can be spanned by a minimal surface lying near ^ and also having a single valued projection.  So far as we know,  there have been no previous results of this type concerning the perturbation of a minimal surface in space. 
From another point of view,  Theorem 2' can be considered as providing a solution of the Plateau problem for a spatial boundary curve lying near a piece of a minimal surface.  The existence of a spanning minimal surface for this case of course also follows from the classical work of Doughs and Rado ( cf.  [ 3 ] ).  In their work,  however,  branch points and self - intersections may occur,  while here the spanning surface not only has no self - intersections but can in fact be expressed in non - parametric form.  Unfortunately,  we are at present unable to determine whether our solution is unique,  or whether it provides the least area,  among all ( parametric ) surfaces spanning the same boundary curve.  We conjecture that this is the case,  though for the moment this is certain only when the competing surfaces are restricted to those which can be expressed in non - parametric form.
